texts.shortText: Very common air-breathing isopod found abundantly on the upper intertidal levels of rocky shores. Head with large eyes and elongate antennae. Body broad, especially in males, dorsally smooth and strongly flattened. Abdomen narrower than thorax, with free segments. Uropods elongate, projecting well beyond end of body and with two equal branches.

Global: Endemic to region.

Local/Regional: Reported in literature from Lüderitz in Namibia to about Hermanus, but dominant from about Cape Peninsula to Cape Agulhas.

Very common around the drift line of rocky shores, wherever drift kelp is cast ashore. May co-occur in mixed populations with both the horned isopod Deto echinata and with the similar L. glabrata. Feed on drift kelp and other algae, and may also scavenge on dead animals. Most active at night, but also on cloudy days, moving down to the shore well into the intertidal to feed and back above the high water mark to shelter during high tide and in heat of the day. May migrate in formidable numbers, swarming over the rocks and kelp wrack.
Mainly kelp but also other drift algae and organic debris.

As with all isopods the eggs are retained within a marsupial pouch between the walking legs of females and hatch into fully developed juveniles. In this species recruitment occurs from spring to autumn and females become reproductive active at an age of 12 months. Life expectancy is about 2 years.

Often in mixed populations with Deto echinata, but that species is easily recognised by the unusual dorsal ‘horns’ on each thoracic segment. Also found together with L. glabrata, but that species has a narrower body and also tends to be dominant along the west coast, whereas L. dilatata is dominant from about Kommetjie on the Cape Peninsula eastwards. Another species, L. natalensis, occurs even further east and into KwaZulu-Natal.
